column2: MAINE PERMIT TEST
column4: Maine
column6: ME

column2: Question Text
column4: Answer1 Text
column6: Answer2 Text
column8: Answer3 Text

column2: 1. This road sign means:
column4: U-turns are prohibited
column6: You may proceed only if the way is clear
column8: You are about to enter a one-way street the wrong way

column2: 2. If a pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green, you should:
column4: proceed unless the pedestrian is in your lane.
column6: proceed because you have the right-of-way.
column8: wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.

column2: 3. Fatigue increases the risk of:
column4: hitting a roadblock.
column6: missing an exit.
column8: falling asleep while driving.

column2: 4. When driving in winter, you should NOT:
column4: use snow tires on all four wheels of your vehicle.
column6: use cruise control.
column8: drive on interstate roads.
column10: check your vehicle's antifreeze level and windshield washer fluid.

column2: 5. This road sign means:
column4: No left turn
column6: No U-Turn
column8: Divided highway ahead

column2: 6. This road sign means:
column4: Drive with caution and be ready to stop
column6: Merge
column8: Do not block intersection
column10: You must come to a complete stop

column2: 7. This road sign means:
column4: No U-turns
column6: No right turn
column8: Do not pass

column2: 8. You should use turn signals to indicate your intention with sufficient time to allow other drivers to see the signal:
column4: BEFORE you move.
column6: if it’s raining.
column8: even if they are short sighted.

column2: 9. You are driving in the left lane and want to change to the right lane. Before changing lanes, you should check your mirrors, signal and:
column4: look over both shoulders for vehicles in front of you.
column6: look over your right shoulder.
column8: accelerate slightly before looking around your vehicle.

column2: 10. Before changing lanes or attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
column4: signal your intention before changing lanes.
column6: check your blind spots and, mirrors.
column8: All of the above.

column2: 11. If your car goes into water, you should:
column4: call the fire department immediately.
column6: remove yourself before it starts to sink.
column8: wait for water to rush in and let it out in small breaths through your nose.

column2: 12. What should you do if a vehicle is approaching head-on in your lane?
column4: Decrease speed, pull over to the right and sound your horn to warn the other driver.
column6: Come to a complete stop and use your horn to warn the vehicles behind you.
column8: Turn off the ignition if your vehicle has power steering.
column10: Pull over to the left and use your emergency lights to stop the other driver.

column2: 13. What should you do if your headlights suddenly go out?
column4: Ease your foot off the gas pedal and brake gently.
column6: Ease your foot off the gas pedal and brake gently.
column8: Brake immediately and activate your emergency lights.
column10: Use your emergency lights, parking lights or directional signals.

column2: 14. Drivers should use high beam headlights when:
column4: there are no oncoming vehicles approaching.
column6: following another vehicle.
column8: when they come within 50 feet of an oncoming vehicle.

column2: 15. If an aggressive driver cuts you off, you should:
column4: sound your horn.
column6: call the police immediately.
column8: stay calm and get out of the aggressive driver's way.
column10: look towards the left side of the road.

column2: 16. From top to bottom, traffic lights are:
column4: red, green and yellow.
column6: green, red and yellow.
column8: red, yellow and green.

column2: 17. On two-lane, two-way streets or highways, you should start left turns close to the center line.
column4: True
column6: False

column2: 18. Which of the following is true about the Anti-Locking Brake System?
column4: Can help improve vehicle stability.
column6: It allows drivers to steer during an emergency braking situation.
column8: It prevents skidding.

column2: 19. Warning signs are normally:
column4: red.
column6: yellow.
column8: green.

column2: 20. If one of your tires blows out, you should:
column4: apply your brakes gently and steer smoothly where you want to go.
column6: apply your brakes immediately.
column8: hold the steering wheel tightly, slowly take your foot off the gas pedal and steer smoothly where you want to go.
column10: pump your brakes and steer where you want to go.

column2: 21. Drivers may continue carefully through a yellow light if:
column4: they already are within the intersection.
column6: they are turning right.
column8: an emergency vehicle is crossing your lane.

column2: 22. This road sign means:
column4: Steep hill
column6: Watch for trucks entering from the side
column8: Merging traffic

column2: 23. When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
column4: before moving into the exit lane.
column6: once you have moved into the exit lane.
column8: once you see the toll booth.
column10: when you first see the exit sign.

column2: 24. Alcohol causes:
column4: loss of concentration.
column6: poor judgment.
column8: reduced perception.

column2: 25. After parking, are you allowed to open a door on the road side of your vehicle?
column4: Yes, always.
column6: No, never.
column8: Yes, but only if it does not interfere with bicyclists and other traffic.
column10: Yes, but only if oncoming vehicles or bicycles are at least 10 feet away.

column2: 26. If you continually pass the other vehicles on a road with one lane in each direction, you will:
column4: get to your destination much faster.
column6: help prevent the chances of a crash occurring due to traffic congestion.
column8: increase your chances of being involved in an accident.

column2: 27. Blind spots are:
column4: Areas to the side or rear of a vehicle that the driver cannot see with use of mirrors.
column6: At night, the darkest areas of a road, where emergency flashers should be used.
column8: lanes reserved for U-turns.
column10: Dangerous intersection where the maximum speed limit is 15 MPH or less.

column2: 28. What does BAC stand for?
column4: Blood Alcohol Commission
column6: Blood Alcohol Content
column8: Blood Alcohol Concentration

column2: 29. Drivers may pass on a two-lane roadway marked with a single solid yellow line on their side of the center line.
column4: False
column6: True

column2: 30. Excessive speed:
column4: increases the likelihood of serious bodily injuries and death.
column6: saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly.
column8: helps you to maneuver around obstacles.

column2: 31. When changing lanes:
column4: change lane before checking the inside rearview mirror.
column6: look over your shoulder to make sure no one is in the blind spot.
column8: slow down and check your left mirror.

column2: 32. Tailgating:
column4: can frustrate other drivers and make them angry.
column6: cannot result in a traffic citation.
column8: helps reduce traffic congestion.

column2: 33. A defensive driver:
column4: considers what other drivers might do and is always prepared to act.
column6: never drives below the speed limit.
column8: knows when it is safe to pass other vehicles.

column2: 34. This road sign means:
column4: School zone ahead
column6: Pedestrian crossing ahead
column8: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead

column2: 35. If you stop along the road at night:
column4: turn off all your lights.
column6: turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams on.
column8: turn off your emergency lights and leave your high beams on.

column2: 36. This road sign warns drivers that:
column4: the dirt on the side of the road is soft.
column6: the road surface ahead changes to a low-type surface or earth road.
column8: vehicles must leave the pavement immediately.

column2: 37. When pedestrians are in a crosswalk, drivers should:
column4: go ahead because drivers have the right-of-way.
column6: pull over to the right and stop.
column8: wait for them to cross.

column2: 38. When taking medication while driving, you should:
column4: drive 20 MPH below the posted speed limit.
column6: consult your physicians and/or pharmacist regarding any prescription medication and its possible effects on driving.
column8: follow other vehicles closely.

column2: 39. A red arrow on a traffic light means:
column4: You may turn in in the direction of the arrow after coming to a complete stop.
column6: You may not turn in the direction of the arrow until a green light or arrow light goes on.
column8: You must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.

column2: 40. When you are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic, you should:
column4: move your vehicle off of the travelled portion of the roadway, if possible.
column6: wait for the police to arrive before moving your vehicle.
column8: not move your vehicle under any circumstances.

column2: 41. Two drivers reach an uncontrolled intersection at the same time. Who has the right of way?
column4: The driver on the right.
column6: No one.
column8: The driver on the left.
column10: The driver who does not control the car.

column2: 42. Night driving can be more difficult because:
column4: speed limits do not apply at night.
column6: visibility is reduced.
column8: the ratio of motorcyles to cars is much higher at night.
column10: vehicle operators tend to drive faster at night.

column2: 43. The minimum drinking age in this State is ____ years.
44. A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
column4: speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
column6: stop until the person is out of the crosswalk.
column8: sound your horn and proceed with caution.

column2: 45. If the entrance lane is too short to allow acceleration to expressway speed, you should:
column4: stop and wait for a large space in traffic.
column6: reduce your speed to 15 MPH or less and blend with traffic.
column8: enter the expressway and accelerate quickly.
column10: accelerate to expressway speed and blend with traffic.

column2: 46. An inattentive driver:
column4: carries on an eye-contact conversation with a passenger while driving.
column6: gazes at objects off the roadway while driving.
column8: daydreams.

column2: 47. After you stop for a school bus, you must:
column4: pass the bus before the red lights stop flashing.
column6: turn off your engine.
column8: wait until the red lights stop flashing.

column2: 48. This sign means:
column4: lane ends, merge left.
column6: road construction.
column8: divided highway ahead.

column2: 49. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, turn the front wheels:
column4: towards the curb.
column6: parallel to the curb.
column8: away from the curb.

column2: 50. Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving ability is permitted:
column4: if it is prescribed by a physician.
column6: under no circumstances.
column8: if you dont feel drowsy.

column2: 51. To drive defensively, you must:
column4: not check behind you through your mirrors.
column6: use only one hand on the wheel.
column8: assume that a driver who approaches a STOP sign on a side road is actually going to stop.

column2: 52. To pass a bicyclist traveling in the same direction on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you should:
column4: continue driving straight, it is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
column6: not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
column8: slow down and wait until there is no oncoming traffic, then pass the bicyclist leaving him or her  sufficient space.
column10: honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.

column2: 53. On what three conditions does your blood alcohol content (BAC) depend?
column4: Your height. How much alcohol you drink. The type of beverage you drink.
column6: Your weight. How much alcohol you drink. How much time passes between drinks.
column8: How fit you are. How much alcohol you drink. Your height.
column10: Your weight. The type of beverage you drink. How fit you are.

column2: 54. When passing another car, you have enough room to return to the driving lane when:
column4: you cannot see the vehicle directly to your right.
column6: you can see both headlights of the car you passed in your rearview mirror.
column8: you have cleared the front bumper of the passed vehicle.
column10: you are at least 50 feet in front of the vehicle.

column2: 55. Drivers can not pass a vehicle on the left if:
column4: they can not safely return to the right lane before they reach a solid yellow center line for the right lane.
column6: they are within 100 feet of a railroad crossing on a two-way roadway.
column8: they approach the top of a hill on a two-way road and can not see over it.

column2: 56. The extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
column4: other drivers when they want to pass the truck.
column6: other drivers when merging onto a freeway.
column8: the truck driver to stop the vehicle.

column2: 57. When following motorcycles, drivers should:
column4: keep more space in front of their vehicle.
column6: reduce the minimum following distance.
column8: keep less space in front of their vehicle.
column10: try to pass them as they have different braking capabilities than other motor vehicles.

column2: 58. When driving near light rail vehicles, drivers should:
column4: expect trains on any track at any time.
column6: never drive around lowered crossing gates.
column8: always obey signs and traffic signals.

column2: 59. This road sign means:
column4: Slippery when wet
column6: Steep downgrade
column8: Stop for other traffic

column2: 60. At a school crossing, drivers should:
column4: None of the other answers is correct.
column6: always sound their horn and stay alert.
column8: watch for children and be ready to stop.
column10: always stop, whether there’s a stop sign or not.
